questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for left total knee arthroplasty. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and osteoarthritis. Preoperative laboratory testing is obtained. The surgery is performed without complications. Medications for thromboprophylaxis and pain management are administered postoperatively. Seven days following the procedure, a repeat complete blood count is obtained and compared with the preoperative results, as shown below. The medication most likely responsible for this patient’s laboratory abnormality has which of the following mechanisms of action?  

Laboratory Value  
Results (at admission)  
Results (current)  
Hemoglobin  
15.2 g/dL
15.0 g/dL
Hematocrit
46%
45%
Leukocyte Count  
9,000/mm3
8,800/mm3
Platelet Count  
150,000/mm3  
65,000/mm3

choices.text: Inhibition of the carboxylation of coagulation factors

questions.solution:
Heparin is commonly used for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis in hospitalized patients. It activates antithrombin III, which in turn inactivates factors IIa and Xa, accounting for heparin’s anticoagulant effects.

One toxicity is heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), characterized by a fall in platelet count and a hypercoagulable state. The condition arises when platelet factor 4 (PF4), a substance released from the alpha granule of platelets, binds with heparin molecules. This complex is immunogenic and may cause the formation of antibodies against the heparin-PF4 complex.

The antibodies then activate platelets, resulting in the microthrombi formation and an overall reduction in the platelet count. The microthrombi can damage a variety of organ systems, including the heart, kidneys, and skin. In addition, antibody-coated platelets are consumed by macrophages, further reducing the platelet count. The reaction usually occurs 5-10 days after heparin initiation and is often associated with a fall in platelet count of 30% or more.

If a patient experiences HIT, heparin should be immediately discontinued. Alternative anticoagulants (e.g., argatroban, fondaparinux) should be initiated to disrupt microthrombi formation.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Blockade of ADP-dependent platelet aggregation:
Incorrect: Medications such as clopidogrel inhibit ADP-dependent platelet aggregation. Common side effects include rash and diarrhea. Ticlopidine, an older agent, works via a similar mechanism and can result in neutropenia. However, it would be unusual for any of these medications to cause thrombocytopenia.  
❌ Inhibition of cyclooxygenase:
Incorrect: Aspirin, celecoxib, and NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen) work by inhibiting cyclooxygenase enzymes. Side effects include increased risk of bleeding, kidney injury, and interstitial nephritis.  
❌ Inhibition of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa:
Incorrect: Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors (e.g, abciximab, tirofiban, and eptifibatide) work via inhibition of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa. These agents can cause acute-onset thrombocytopenia that manifests within 24 hours of starting the medication. In contrast, this patient’s thrombocytopenia was detected almost a week after starting these medications. Moreover, glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors are rarely used for clotting prophylaxis after surgery.  
❌ Inhibition of the carboxylation of coagulation factors:
Incorrect: Warfarin inhibits vitamin K-dependent carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. Side effects include increased risk of bleeding, transient hypercoagulability, and skin necrosis.  
✅ Activation of antithrombin:
Correct: See the Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the emergency department to evaluate right leg pain and swelling for three days. The symptoms have worsened to the extent that the patient cannot bear weight on her right leg. She does not have shortness of breath, chest pain, or lightheadedness. The patient recently traveled from India to the United States via a 23-hour-long flight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a swollen, warm, and tender right leg compared to the left leg. Duplex ultrasonography reveals a non-compressible right femoral vein. The patient is provided with a standard dose of warfarin in conjunction with low molecular weight heparin bridging therapy. A physician decides to pursue genetic analysis involving the VKORC1 gene on a subsequent visit. The patient is found to have the homozygous mutation (AA) in the promoter region of the VKORC1 gene, resulting in diminished protein expression. This patient is at risk of which of the following complications following initiation of warfarin therapy?

choices.text: No increased risk when compared to wildtype VKORC1 gene

questions.solution:
There is wide inter-individual variability in the dosage of warfarin required to achieve target anticoagulation. Approximately half of this variability is known to be caused by clinical or lifestyle factors (e.g., a patient’s age, weight, BMI, gender, smoking status, existing conditions, and concomitant medications), as well as by genetic factors–including variants in the VKORC1 or CYP2C9 gene.  

The VKORC1 and CYP2C9 genotypes are the most critical genetic determinants of warfarin dosing. Warfarin targets the vitamin K epoxide reductase enzyme (VKORC1), catalyzing the rate-limiting step in vitamin K recycling (converting vitamin K epoxide to vitamin K). This, in turn, inhibits the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors.  

A common non-coding variant, VKORC1, c.-1639G>A, is associated with increased sensitivity to warfarin. Patients with this variant require lower doses of warfarin, as standard doses may result in a supratherapeutic INR and subsequent bleeding complications. The polymorphism occurs in the promoter region of the VKORC1 gene and is thought to alter a transcription factor binding site, leading to lower protein expression. As a result, patients starting warfarin therapy who are carrying at least one “A” (mutated) allele at the -1639 locus require lower initial and maintenance doses compared with patients carrying a G/G (wild type) genotype at this locus.  

Less commonly, missense mutations in VKORC1 can lead to warfarin resistance and higher dose requirements. Lastly, The CYP2C9 enzyme metabolizes warfarin, and a dose reduction is recommended for individuals who are poor or intermediate metabolizers (variants CYP2C9*2 and *3).  



Option Analysis

✅ Supratherapeutic INR:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subtherapeutic INR:
Incorrect: Missense mutations in VKORC1 can lead to warfarin resistance and subtherapeutic INR, leading to higher dose requirements. Polymorphisms in the promoter region of the VKORC1 gene lead to increased warfarin sensitivity.  
❌ Skin necrosis:
Incorrect: Warfarin-induced skin necrosis typically occurs due to a 50% decrease in protein C production during the first few days of warfarin therapy (shorter half-life than factors II and X).  It can be avoided by administering heparin for five days to enable anticoagulation during the initial, transient hypercoagulable state.  
❌ No increased risk when compared to wildtype VKORC1 gene:
Incorrect: It is recommended to use only 60% of the standard initial dose of warfarin in patients with a  homozygous mutation (AA) in the promoter region of VKORC1 gene due to increased warfarin sensitivity.  
❌ Vascular calcification:
Incorrect: An association between chronic warfarin use and arterial calcifications has been reported in some studies; however, it is not affected by warfarin metabolism.

questions.text: An 84-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of spontaneous epistaxis. The patient is currently taking apixaban for atrial fibrillation. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient has ongoing hemorrhage from the left nare. Direct pressure is applied to the nares, which does not result in hemostasis. Medication is administered directly to the nasal mucosa that acts by blocking the reuptake of catecholamines, including dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient on anticoagulation is administered medication with effects consistent with an indirect sympathomimetic agonist. Of the medications listed, only cocaine exerts these specific effects and can be used to manage epistaxis, primarily via vasoconstriction of vessels abutting the nasal mucosa.

Indirect sympathomimetic agonists work by indirectly increasing the concentration of endogenous catecholamines within the synaptic cleft. These agents achieve this effect via displacement of stored norepinephrine or epinephrine from presynaptic vesicles, reuptake inhibition, or inhibition of their metabolism by monoamine oxidase or catechol-o-methyltransferase.

Examples of indirect sympathomimetic medications include cocaine, ephedrine, and amphetamines. Cocaine can be used clinically to tamponade mucosal bleeding, particularly in the nasopharynx, and provide anesthesia for adult nasal mucosal surgery. Ephedrine is primarily used to treat clinically significant hypotension perioperatively and for hypotension induced by spinal or epidural anesthesia. Various amphetamines are used to treat attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

Option Analysis

✅ Cocaine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tranexamic acid:
Incorrect: Tranexamic acid is a synthetic derivative of the amino acid lysine that inhibits plasmin formation and displaces plasminogen from the fibrin surface. While this medication can be used to treat epistaxis, it does not exert the mechanism of action of an indirect sympathomimetic.  
❌ Phenylephrine:
Incorrect: Phenylephrine is a nasal decongestant that works via α1-agonism in the arterioles of the nasal mucosa.  
❌ Ephedrine:
Incorrect: Ephedrine works via indirect stimulation of the adrenergic receptor system by increasing the activity of norepinephrine at the postsynaptic α- and β-receptors. It has little effect on dopamine and serotonin receptors. Moreover, it is not used in the management of epistaxis.  
❌ Sertraline:
Incorrect: Sertraline is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor. It is not used in the management of epistaxis.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of bleeding gums over the past 18 hours. After brushing her teeth in the morning, the patient noticed persistent oozing of blood from the gums. Past medical history is notable for type II diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation, for which she is taking appropriate medications. She recently visited her family doctor for evaluation of tinea versicolor and was started on an oral antifungal medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 136/84 mmHg, pulse is 92/min and irregularly irregular, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination is unremarkable except for oral examination, which reveals bleeding and mildly swollen gums. The patient’s international normalized ratio (INR) is 3.6 as compared to 2.2 two weeks earlier. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
The cytochrome P450 system is classified by similar gene sequences. Enzymes are assigned a family number (e.g., CYP1, CYP2), a subfamily letter (e.g., CYP1A, CYP2D), and a number for the isoform or individual enzyme (e.g., CYP1A1, CYP2D6). It is important to note that medications that share a common metabolism pathway may cause drug-drug interactions.

Typically, if a drug acts as a CYP inducer, then it causes concurrently administered drugs metabolized by the same CYP isozyme to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure.

In contrast, if a drug acts as a CYP inhibitor, then it causes other drugs to accumulate to toxic levels where overdoses and side effects may occur. For example, this patient, who was on warfarin and then developed increased bleeding despite no changes in warfarin dosing, was likely given a CYP inhibitor. The CYP inhibitor slowed the metabolism of warfarin, thereby increasing serum warfarin levels to supratherapeutic levels.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Ketoconazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Griseofulvin:
Incorrect: Griseofulvin, an antifungal medication, is a CYP inducer, which causes medications to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure. In this patient’s case, CYP inducers in conjunction with warfarin would likely lead to subtherapeutic INR levels and subsequent episodes of strokes or other embolic phenomena.   
❌ Topical clotrimazole   :
Incorrect: Topical antifungals have minimal effect on the liver. These medications would be neither CYP inducers nor inhibitors.   
❌ Carbamazepine:
Incorrect: Carbamazepine, an antiepileptic medication, is a CYP inducer, which causes medications to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure. In this patient’s case, CYP inducers in conjunction with warfarin would likely lead to subtherapeutic INR levels and subsequent episodes of strokes or other embolic phenomena.   
❌ Rifampin:
Incorrect: Rifampin, an antibacterial medication, is a CYP inducer, which causes medications to be metabolized faster and excreted. As a result, plasma levels of a specific drug may not reach therapeutic levels if it is cleared too quickly by the body, leading to treatment failure. In this patient’s case, CYP inducers in conjunction with warfarin would likely lead to subtherapeutic INR levels and subsequent episodes of strokes or other embolic phenomena.

questions.text: A woman presents to the physician because of pain and swelling in the right breast. The woman has been lactating for 2-weeks. Physical examination reveals tenderness, erythema, and swelling in the right breast and enlarged, tender right axillary lymph nodes. Which of the following best describes the lymphatic drainage pathway from the inflamed lymph nodes?

choices.text: Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then the junction between the right subclavian and internal jugular vein
Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then directly into the superior vena cava
Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then into the thoracic duct
Drains into the thoracic duct and then the junction between the left subclavian and internal jugular vein
Drains into the thoracic duct and then directly into the right heart

questions.solution:
The lymphatic system is responsible for returning lymph fluid into the bloodstream. It is also involved in immune surveillance and carries specific molecules (e.g. lipids) into the bloodstream.

The lymphatic system consists of vessels that drain into the major lymphatic trunks. The primary lymphatic trunks are the lumbar trunks, bronchomediastinal trunks, subclavian trunks, jugular trunks, and intestinal trunks. These trunks drain into either the right lymphatic duct or thoracic duct, returning the lymph into the bloodstream.

The right lymphatic duct receives lymphatic drainage from the right upper extremity, right side of the head, and right chest. It empties into the bloodstream between the right subclavian and right internal jugular veins. In contrast, lymphatic drainage from every other body part enters the thoracic duct and empties into the bloodstream at the junction between the left subclavian and left internal jugular vein.    

Option Analysis

✅ Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then the junction between the right subclavian and internal jugular vein  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then directly into the superior vena cava  :
Incorrect: The right axillary lymph nodes do drain into the right lymphatic duct. However, the right lymphatic duct then empties into the bloodstream at the junction between the right subclavian and internal jugular vein, instead of the superior vena cava.  
❌ Drains into the right lymphatic duct and then into the thoracic duct  :
Incorrect: The right lymphatic duct drains into the right subclavian and internal jugular vein junction, not the thoracic duct.  
❌ Drains into the thoracic duct and then the junction between the left subclavian and internal jugular vein:
Incorrect: The right upper extremity, right side of the head, and right chest drain into the right lymphatic duct, not the thoracic duct  
❌ Drains into the thoracic duct and then directly into the right heart  :
Incorrect: The right upper extremity, right side of the head, and right chest drain into the right lymphatic duct, not the thoracic duct. Furthermore, the thoracic duct drains into the junction between the left subclavian and internal jugular vein, instead of directly into the heart.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the histology of the spleen and the different types of cells and structures found in it. A biopsy is taken from a spleen and is examined under a microscope, as shown below. Which of the following best describes area A?

choices.text: It is a highly vascularized area containing sinusoids and is responsible for removing old red blood cells.
It contains dense connective tissue and surrounds the spleen
It contains a group of mature T-lymphocytes that surround a central arteriole and is part of the adaptive immune system.
The marginal center where antigen presentation occurs

questions.solution:
The spleen is the largest lymphatic organ. It receives blood supply via the splenic artery. Histologically, it is divided into two regions, i.e., the red pulp and the white pulp.  

The red pulp of the spleen is a highly vascularized structure that contains the parenchyma and venous sinuses. The venous sinuses are a chain of interconnected vascular spaces lined with endothelial cells and are responsible for filtering the blood. These sinuses join and drain into the splenic vein.  

The white pulp of the spleen is comprised of follicles. The center of the follicle is made of the germinal matrix, which contains mature and activated B-lymphocytes. Surrounding the germinal matrix is the mantle zone, which includes B-lymphocytes and macrophages. Finally, the outermost layer of the follicle is called the marginal zone. It contains B-lymphocytes, macrophages, and dendritic cells, where antigen-presenting cells catch blood-borne antigens and present them to lymphocytes, allowing an adaptive immune response. The T-lymphocytes are primarily found in a periarteriolar lymphoid sheath (PALS), which immediately surrounds a central arteriole.  


Option Analysis

✅ It is a highly vascularized area containing sinusoids and is responsible for removing old red blood cells.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It contains dense connective tissue and surrounds the spleen  :
Incorrect: The splenic capsule contains dense connective tissue and surrounds the spleen. Area A in the picture points to the red pulp, not the splenic capsule.   
❌ It contains a group of mature T-lymphocytes that surround a central arteriole and is part of the adaptive immune system.  :
Incorrect: The white pulp contains the periarteriolar lymphoid sheath (PALS), a group of T-lymphocytes surrounding a central arteriole. Area A in the picture is pointing to the red pulp.  
❌ Contains the germinal centers  :
Incorrect: The germinal centers are packed with mature and activated B-cells found in the follicles' center. These follicles are located in the white pulp.  
❌ The marginal center where antigen presentation occurs  :
Incorrect: The marginal center is the outermost layer of the follicles and is found in the white pulp.

questions.text:
Two biopsies were taken from the lymph nodes of two different children to examine the changes in the follicles present in the outer cortex. The first specimen (Specimen A) and second specimen (Specimen B) are shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the difference in appearance between the follicles in specimen A and specimen B?


Source: histologyguide.com

choices.text: Follicles in specimen B contain active B lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation
Follicles in specimen A contain active B lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation
Follicles in specimen B contain active T lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation
Follicles in specimen B represent a metastatic cancer

questions.solution:
The lymph nodes are encapsulated immune organs that are scattered throughout the body. In the outer cortex of these lymph nodes are the lymphoid follicles. These follicles are the site of B-cell proliferation and maturation and can be divided into two types:
  • Primary follicles: These follicles are found in Naive lymph nodes. They are dense and inactive.


  • Secondary follicles: These follicles are found in activated lymph nodes. Once B lymphocytes get activated, they start proliferating and maturating. In addition, a germinal matrix forms in the center of the secondary follicle, and it is the site where B-cells transform into plasma cells. These germinal matrices give the secondary follicles a pale appearance.


Option Analysis

✅ Follicles in specimen B contain active B lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation:
See Main Explanation.
❌ Follicles in specimen A contain active B lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation:
Incorrect: Specimen A follicles are primary follicles that are dense and quiescent, while in specimen B, they are secondary follicles that are active and pale due to the presence of a germinal matrix in the center of the follicle.
❌ Follicles in specimen B contain active T lymphocytes with a germinal matrix formation:
Incorrect: The follicles are the site of B-cell localization and maturation, while T-cells are found in the paracortex (the region between the follicles and the medulla).
❌ Follicles in specimen B represent a metastatic cancer:
Incorrect: The specimen in picture B represents an activated secondary follicle with a pale germinal matrix in the center. This is due to the activation of B lymphocytes, which are not cancerous cells.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of joint pain. She tells the physician that she has had pain in the joints of her hands and wrists for the last eight months, in addition to morning stiffness lasting more than an hour. Physical examination reveals swelling, warmth, and deformities in the proximal interphalangeal joints and the wrists. Her serum analysis is positive for rheumatoid factor and anti-citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP). In addition, her C-reactive protein levels are elevated. Which of the following is the primary cytokine responsible for producing and releasing C-reactive protein?
questions.solution:
Interleukins are cytokines that modulate the immune response and inflammation. One of the major proinflammatory cytokines is interleukin-6 (IL-6), secreted by immune cells like macrophages and lymphocytes and non-immune cells like endothelial cells in the damaged or infected tissue.  

The effects of interleukin-2 are widespread and include effects on immune cells, the central nervous system, and the liver. IL-6 helps in the growth and differentiation of B-cells. Also, it is one of the main mediators of fever (which is also mediated by interleukin-1). Finally, IL-6 stimulates the liver to increase the production of acute-phase reactants, which can be used as markers of inflammation. Such acute-phase reactants include C-reactive protein, ferritin, hepcidin, serum amyloid A, fibrinogen, and haptoglobin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Interleukin-6  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Interleukin-10  :
Incorrect: IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that attenuates the immune system and inhibits activated macrophages and other immune cells. It does not stimulate the release of acute-phase proteins.  
❌ Interleukin-2  :
Incorrect: IL-2 stimulates the growth and differentiation of lymphocytes and natural killer cells, but it is not involved in stimulating the release of acute phase reactants.  
❌ Interleukin-8  :
Incorrect: IL-8 is released by macrophages and acts as a chemotactic factor for neutrophils to attract them to the site of inflammation. However, it does not stimulate the release of acute-phase reactants.  
❌ Interleukin-1  :
Incorrect: IL-1 is a major proinflammatory cytokine that helps in mediating acute inflammation and also is involved in fever. Although it also increases the synthesis and release of acute-phase reactants, it is not the primary cytokine involved in this process.

questions.text: An inflammatory response is observed to determine the different aspects of it. During the inflammation, blood vessels were noted to dilate and increase their permeability to certain cells. Neutrophils were noted to leave the vessels and aim directly at the site of inflammation. Which of the following molecules help direct and attract neutrophils to the site of inflammation?
questions.solution:
During inflammation, blood vessels dilate and increase their permeability to allow the fluids and immune cells to reach the damaged or infected organ in order to clear the organ from infection and debris. One of the major cells that are involved in inflammation are neutrophils.  

Neutrophils are major cells in acute inflammation, and they are responsible for the phagocytosis of bacteria and other pathogens, as well as dead tissue, and this helps clear the tissue and allow for regeneration and repair. In order for neutrophils to reach the site of inflammation, several factors play a role in directing them. These agents are called neutrophil chemotactic agents. The neutrophil chemotactic agents are C5a, interleukin-8, leukotriene B4 (LTB4), kallikrein, platelet-activating factor, and N-formylmethionine, which is found on bacterial surfaces.  

Option Analysis

❌ Interleukin-6  :
Incorrect: IL-6 is an important mediator of fever and of the acute phase response. IL-6 is not, however, a chemotactic agent for neutrophils.  
❌ C3a:
Incorrect: C3a is an effector of the complement system. However, it is not a chemotactic agent for neutrophils.  
❌ Interleukin-10  :
Incorrect: IL-10 is a cytokine involved in immunoregulation and downregulates the expression of Th1 cytokines. It is not a chemotactic agent for neutrophils  
❌ Interleukin-17  :
Incorrect: IL-17 is involved in inducing and mediating proinflammatory responses and is commonly associated with allergic responses. IL-17 is not a chemotactic agent for neutrophils.  
✅ Interleukin-8  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying the immune response against different types of antigens. In the study, the immune response against a polysaccharide antigen of Leuconostoc mesenteroides bacteria is compared with the response when the same antigen is conjugated with a protein. Which of the following regarding the immune responses in the two cases is true?

choices.text: The conjugated antigen results in a more robust immune response that involves T-cells and B-cells
The polysaccharide-only antigen creates a longer-lasting immune response.
The polysaccharide-only antigen activates both humoral and cellular immunity
The conjugated antigen results in a more robust immune response that only involves B-cells
Both conjugated antigens and polysaccharide-only antigens result in similar immune responses.

questions.solution:
Thymus-independent (TI) antigens are polysaccharides that stimulate B-cells to induce an immune response without stimulating T-cells. These antigens cannot stimulate the T-cells because polysaccharides cannot be presented to T-cells on MHC. Therefore, T-cells cannot stimulate the T-cells because polysaccharides cannot be presented to T-cells on MHC, and thus, T-cells cannot activate.  

On the other hand, thymus-dependent antigens contain a protein component and can be presented to T-cells on MHC, therefore involving activation of the T-cells. This results in a more robust and longer-lasting immune response because the T-cells release cytokines that stimulate class-switching, affinity maturation, and memory B- and T-cell formation.  

Subunit vaccines use a highly immunogenic subunit to produce active immunity against certain microorganisms. Some of these subunits can be polysaccharides, such as the capsular polysaccharide used in vaccines against Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae type B and Neissieria meningitides.   

When the polysaccharide antigen is used alone in the vaccines, it will result in a thymus-independent response, a weaker response that will not last long. Therefore, booster doses and adjuvants are usually required to maintain immunity.  

On the other hand, the capsular polysaccharide can be conjugated with a protein. This results in switching the immune response to a thymus-dependent reaction involving T-cells because the antigen can be presented to T-cells and activate them, causing a much more robust and longer-lasting immune response.  

Option Analysis

✅ The conjugated antigen results in a more robust immune response that involves T-cells and B-cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The polysaccharide-only antigen creates a longer-lasting immune response.  :
Incorrect: Polysaccharide-only antigens are thymus-independent antigens that cannot activate T-cells. This results in a weaker immune response and a shorter one.  
❌ The polysaccharide-only antigen activates both humoral and cellular immunity  :
Incorrect: Polysaccharide-only antigens are thymus-independent antigens and cannot activate T-cells; they only activate B-cells.  
❌ The conjugated antigen results in a more robust immune response that only involves B-cells  :
Incorrect: Conjugation of a polysaccharide antigen results in switching the immune response to a thymus-dependent immune response that involves T-cells and B-cells.  
❌ Both conjugated antigens and polysaccharide-only antigens result in similar immune responses.  :
Incorrect: The polysaccharide antigens are thymus-independent antigens that cannot activate T-cells. Conjugated antigens can activate T-cells and result in thymus-dependent responses that are stronger and longer lasting.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the clinic with a pruritic rash on his abdomen for one day. It began as a macular rash that progressed to pruritic papules. This inflammatory process is mediated by which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
This patient’s skin findings of an itchy, red, papular rash are characteristic of contact dermatitis secondary to possible nickel exposure from his belt, which is a type IV (delayed-type) hypersensitivity reaction.   

Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is initiated by CD8+ T cells (also known as killer T cells or cytotoxic T cells) and CD4+ T cells, also known as helper T cells. The former causes direct lysis of the cells with antigen via perforin and granzymes.  

CD4+ T cells, on the other hand, are only activated when the antigen is presented to them via an antigen-presenting cell or APC (e.g. Langerhans cells). Once bound, a series of events causes CD4+ naive T cells to be differentiated into type 1 helper T (TH1) cells. These cells release the interleukin-2, which helps it and other T cells in the area proliferate, and interferon-gamma, which activates phagocytes like macrophages and creates more TH1 cells. Those activated macrophages release pro-inflammatory cytokines like tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1, and interleukin-6, which enhance endothelial permeability to allow for more immune cells into the area, all leading to local swelling or edema redness, and warmth as well as systemic symptoms like a fever.   

Option Analysis

✅ T-cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ B-cells  :
Incorrect: Type IV hypersensitivity reaction is different from type I-III hypersensitivity because it does not involve B-cells and related antibody release.  
❌ Neutrophils:
Incorrect: Neutrophils are recruited late in type IV hypersensitivity reaction when the cytokines from activated macrophages cause leakiness in the endothelial barriers.  
❌ Macrophages:
Incorrect: Macrophages are recruited and activated late in type IV hypersensitivity reaction when type 1 helper T cell or a TH1 cell releases interferon-gamma.  
❌ Natural killer cells   :
Incorrect: Natural killer cells are not directly involved in type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Research is done to study the origins of hematological cells. It was found that all these cells are produced in the bone marrow. A cell known as CD34+ stem cell is responsible for the production of hematopoiesis and the production of all blood cells including erythrocytes and leukocytes. Which of the following is correct about myeloid and lymphoid cells?

choices.text: All immune cells differentiate from myeloid stem cells
Myeloid cells are produced in the bone marrow, while lymphoid cells are produced in peripheral tissues
Macrophages are granulocytes that originate from myeloblasts
All innate immune cells are myeloid cells
Natural killer cells differentiate from lymphoid stem cells

questions.solution:
Hematological cells (erythrocytes, leukocytes, platelets) are all produced in the bone marrow and they all originate from the same stem cell called multipotent CD34+ stem cell. The multipotent stem cell then differentiates into either myeloid stem cell or lymphoid stem cell, and each then produces different types of hematological cells.  

Myeloid stem cells differentiate into 4 types of other stem cells which each produce different cells. The first type of stem cell is the erythroblasts, which produce erythrocytes. The second is the megakaryoblasts, which produce platelets. The third type is the myeloblasts. The myeloblasts are responsible for producing granulocytes, which are eosinophils, basophils, mast cells, and neutrophils. These cells are called granulocytes due to the fact that they contain granules in their cytoplasm. Finally, the fourth type is the monoblasts, which produce monocytes that can stay in the blood or go into tissues and become macrophages and dendritic cells.  

On the other hand, the lymphoblasts or lymphoid progenitor cells produce 3 types of cells. These are the T-cells, B-cells, and natural killer cells.  


Option Analysis

❌ All immune cells differentiate from myeloid stem cells  :
Incorrect: Granulocytes, as well as monocytes, mast cells, and dendritic cells, all originate from the myeloid stem cells. However, natural killer cells and lymphocytes differentiate from the lymphoid progenitor cells.  
❌ Myeloid cells are produced in the bone marrow, while lymphoid cells are produced in peripheral tissues:
Incorrect: Both myeloid and lymphoid cells are produced in the bone marrow.  
❌ Macrophages are granulocytes that originate from myeloblasts  :
Incorrect: Macrophages originate from myeloid stem cells which differentiate into monoblasts. Monoblasts then give rise to macrophages in the peripheral tissues or monocytes in the blood.  
❌ All innate immune cells are myeloid cells  :
Incorrect: Although most innate immune cells are myeloid cells, natural killer cells are part of the innate immune system but are lymphoid cells.  
✅ Natural killer cells differentiate from lymphoid stem cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A CD4+ and CD8+ double-positive T-cell are present within the thymic cortex. It binds successfully with MHC I molecules expressed by cortical epithelial cells and travels to the thymic medulla. Which of the following stages in T-cell development did this cell just complete?
questions.solution:
T-cells undergo positive and negative selection in the thymus as part of the maturation process.  

After arriving in the thymus, T-cells will begin expressing CD4 and CD8 surface receptors. They also undergo VDJ recombination to produce a T-cell receptor. Afterward, each T-cell undergoes positive selection in the thymic cortex, which involves testing the ability of the T-cell to bind with MHC I and II receptors on the surface of thymic cortex cells. T-cells that have an MHC affinity and can serve useful functions in the body are allowed to survive and undergo negative selection. In contrast, T-cells that fail to bind with MHC receptors will undergo apoptosis.  

The next step involves negative selection, which helps ensure the thymus is not producing self-reactive T-cells. This stage occurs in the thymic medulla, which expresses the AIRE gene and enables the cells to express antigens generally found in other body organs (e.g., bones, ovaries, pancreas). It essentially allows the thymus to serve as a microcosm of the entire body. T-cells that bind self-antigens undergo apoptosis. Those who do not bind will survive, mature, and downregulate CD4 or CD8 receptors to become a single positive T-cell.  

Option Analysis

❌ VDJ rearrangement  :
Incorrect: VDJ rearrangement is a process of somatic recombination that occurs during the early stages of T and B-cell development. This process enables the body to generate various antibodies and T-cell receptors. However, the process of VDJ recombination would not entail T-cells binding with MHC molecules in the thymus.  
❌ Self-tolerance  :
Incorrect: Self-tolerance is when the body’s immune system does not attack antigens expressed by its organs. The negative selection process, when T-cells that bind to self-antigens presented by MHC molecules on thymic medullary cells, will undergo apoptosis, help preserve self-tolerance. In contrast, the process described in this question stem is more consistent with positive selection.  
❌ Autocrine stimulation  :
Incorrect: Autocrine stimulation is when a cell secretes a chemical messenger (e.g., cytokine, hormone) that binds to receptors on the same cell. For instance, during T-cell activation, T-cells release IL-2, which subsequently binds to IL-2 receptors on the same cell. In contrast, the process described in this question stem is more consistent with positive selection.
✅ Positive selection  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Negative selection  :
Incorrect: Negative selection is when T-cells that bind to self-antigens presented by MHC molecules on thymic medullary cells will undergo apoptosis. This process ensures the self-tolerance of the immune system. In contrast, the developing T-cell in this vignette underwent further maturation after successfully binding with an MHC I molecule,  which is more consistent with positive selection.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician to receive his scheduled vaccination. The infant is scheduled for hepatitis B vaccination. Which of the following is true regarding this vaccine?

choices.text: It is a live attenuated vaccine.
It is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.

questions.solution:
The Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine. Subunit vaccines contain only a fragment of the pathogen that contains the parts of the pathogen which stimulate the immune system the most.  

The fragment in subunit vaccines can be a polysaccharide or a protein. For example, the Streptococcus pneumoniae vaccine contains a capsular polysaccharide that can produce immunity against the pathogen. In polysaccharide-only vaccines, B-cells stimulate an immune response without stimulating T-cells (also known as a thymus-independent antigen). Therefore, the polysaccharide can be conjugated in with a protein to switch the response to a thymus-dependent reaction which is more robust. The vaccines against Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae type B, and Neissieria meningitidis are all subunit vaccines that contain the capsular polysaccharide and are conjugated with a protein. Other subunit vaccines include the hepatitis B vaccine, HPV vaccine, and pertussis vaccine.  

Subunit vaccines are safe and have fewer side effects. However, they do not produce a robust immune response compared to live-attenuated vaccines. And therefore, it may require booster doses or adjuvants to stimulate the immune response.  

Option Analysis

✅ It is a subunit vaccine.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is a whole-cell vaccine.  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine, not a whole-cell vaccine. Whole-cell vaccines are live attenuated vaccines and inactivated vaccines.  
❌ It is a polysaccharide vaccine.  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine that contains hepatitis B surface antigen (HbsAg), which is a protein, not a polysaccharide.  
❌ It is a live attenuated vaccine.  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine.  
❌ It is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.  :
Incorrect: The hepatitis B vaccine is not contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies. Also, it is not contraindicated in patients with autoimmune disorders or pregnant or lactating women.

questions.text: A researcher identified that an enzyme from phagocytes is responsible for the greenish color of sputum. This enzyme is called myeloperoxidase and is part of the oxidative burst that takes place in the phagolysosome. This enzyme catalyzes which of the following reactions?

choices.text: Creating hypochlorite from chloride ions and hydrogen peroxide.

questions.solution:
Phagocytosis is a process that involves engulfing and destroying pathogens by immune cells called phagocytes (e.g., neutrophils, and macrophages). These pathogens are engulfed in a phagosome, which is part of the cell membrane of the phagocyte. Once inside the cell, the phagosome is joined by the lysosome to create a phagolysosome where the pathogen is destroyed.  

One of the effective mechanisms for pathogen destruction in the phagolysosome is called oxidative burst, which involves the creation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) that damages the cell membrane of the pathogen and thereby resulting in death of the pathogen.  

The oxidative burst starts with an enzyme called NADPH oxidase which oxidizes NADPH to NADP+ and results in the formation of superoxide (O2-) from oxygen. Superoxide is then converted to hydrogen peroxide by superoxide dismutase. Finally, hydrogen peroxide joins with chloride ions to form bleach (hydrochlorite, HOCl) by a reaction catalyzed by myeloperoxidase. All the formed ROS (e.g., superoxide, hydrogen peroxide, bleach) causes damage to the pathogen’s cell membrane, although bleach is the most effective.  


Option Analysis

✅ Creating hypochlorite from chloride ions and hydrogen peroxide.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Converting NADPH to NADP+  :
Incorrect: The first step in the oxidative burst is done by NADPH oxidase, which catalyzes the oxidation of NADPH to NADP, thus creating superoxide (O2-) from oxygen (O2).
❌ Converting oxygen to superoxide  :
Incorrect: The first step in the oxidative burst is done by NADPH oxidase, which catalyzes the oxidation of NADPH to NADP, thus creating superoxide (O2-) from oxygen (O2).  
❌ Converting superoxide to hydrogen peroxide  :
Incorrect: The conversion of superoxide to hydrogen peroxide is catalyzed by the enzyme superoxide dismutase.  
❌ Converting hydrogen peroxide to water  :
Incorrect: Catalase enzyme converts hydrogen peroxide to water. This step is not a part of the oxidative burst.

questions.text: An activated B cell located in the spleen binds an antigen and is activated via cytokines from a nearby T cell. An enzyme is then expressed in the B cell, which causes random nucleotides to be changed in the B cell receptor variable region. Subsequent generations of daughter cells of this B cell develop progressively stronger binding to this antigen. Which of the following correctly describes this process?
questions.solution:
B cells have a myriad of ways to improve their diversity and strength (affinity) of antigen recognition. During the maturation process, B cells (and T cells) undergo VDJ rearrangement, randomly altering the variable (antibody-binding) region of the B cell and T cell receptors. Activated B cells within the spleen and lymph nodes also undergo somatic hypermutation and subsequent affinity maturation. When these activated B cells bind to an antigen, they express CD40, which binds to the CD40 ligand from nearby T cells. This binding causes the T cells to secrete cytokines which induce an enzyme in B cells called AID (activation-induced cytidine deaminase). AID then replaces many cytidine nucleotides with uridine in single strands of DNA within the B cell receptor (BCR) variable region. These uridine nucleotides are then “repaired” via base excision or mismatch repair, eventually leading to a strand of DNA different from the original. As replication of this activated B cell progresses, this somatic hypermutation occurs many times in many different ways, presenting a slightly different antigen-binding site (variable region) in each daughter cell.    

The daughter B cells with a stronger affinity to the original antigen will bind to it more strongly than other daughter B cells. These daughter B cells will then go on to replicate, allowing more and more B cells with a strong affinity to develop. The B cells that developed BCR with less affinity during this random process will eventually die out as they cannot compete with the affinity of the other daughter B cells. This entire process is referred to as affinity maturation, as over time, the affinity of the BCR to the antigen matures and becomes stronger.  

Option Analysis

❌ Isotype switching  :
Incorrect: Isotype switching refers to a change within the constant region (Fc) of a B cell receptor or antibody, causing B cell receptors or antibodies to convert between IgA, IgD, IgE, IgG, and IgM. This process does not involve random nucleotide changes or changes in antigen affinity.    
❌ VDJ rearrangement  :
Incorrect: While this process also has the purpose of improving antigen-receptor diversity and affinity, it occurs while B cells are maturing and occurs without the involvement of T cells.    
❌ Peripheral tolerance  :
Incorrect: Peripheral tolerance refers to the process of regulatory T cells (Treg cells)  inhibiting other immune cells that are not functioning properly.    
✅ Affinity maturation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.    
❌ MHC binding  :
Incorrect: Major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is the receptor on which antigens can be presented to other immune cells. The process in the question above is not referring to the process of MHC binding.

questions.text: A blood sample containing a large number of dendritic cells and natural killer cells is isolated from a patient with severe autoimmune disease. When the blood is exposed to T cells expressing high levels of PD-1 receptors, the T cells remain active. When the blood is exposed to T cells expressing high levels of CTLA-4, or high levels of Fas receptors, the T cells undergo inactivation or apoptosis, respectively. Which of the following processes is dysfunctional in this patient?
questions.solution:
The immune system has many different ways to modulate, limit, or kill different immune cells. Regulatory T cells (Treg cells), clonal anergy, clonal deletion, and clonal exhaustion are the main components of this process. Treg cells develop in the thymus and modulate the immune system in three major ways:  

1) increased expression of IL-2 and adenosine receptors on their surface  
2) secretion of cytokines which limit antigen-presenting cells’ ability to present ligands  
3) secretion of cytokines which cause antigen-presenting cells to express more PD-1 ligands  

As the immune response is winding down, clonal anergy and clonal deletion take place.  

In clonal anergy, Treg cells secrete cytokines which cause antigen-presenting cells (APC) to downregulate B7 expression and cause T cells to upregulate CTLA-4 expression. CTLA-4 is a protein receptor constitutively expressed in Treg cells that function to downregulate the immune response. CTLA-4 binds much more strongly to B7 than does CD28, and causes inactivation of the T cell.  

In clonal deletion, T cells express more Fas receptors on their surface. This allows the Fas ligand on CD8+ T cells and natural killer cells to bind to Fas receptors and secretes caspase enzymes, which cause apoptosis of the T cells.  

In clonal exhaustion, T cells that have been around for a long time will express more PD-1 (programed death) receptors on their surface. APCs expressing PD-1 ligands can then bind to this T cell via PD-1 and inactivate it.   

Option Analysis

❌ Affinity maturation  :
Incorrect: This refers to the process whereby cells that underwent somatic hypermutation lead to daughter cells with a progressively stronger affinity for a specific antigen. This question involves cell-to-cell interactions rather than cell-to-antigen interactions.  
❌ Clonal anergy  :
Incorrect: This is an immune-modulating mechanism by which regulatory T cells secrete cytokines causing increased expression of CTLA-4 (a protein receptor that downregulates immune responses) on T cells and decreased expression of B7 on antigen-presenting (e.g., dendritic) cells. Since the T cells expressing CTLA-4 that were added to this blood sample were inactivated, we can assume clonal anergy is working.    
❌ Clonal deletion  :
Incorrect: This is an immune-modulating mechanism by which Fas ligands on CD8+ T cells or natural killer cells bind to Fas receptors on T cells, inactivating (or destroying) them. Since the T cells expressing Fas receptors that were added to this blood sample were destroyed, we can assume clonal deletion is working.
✅ Clonal exhaustion  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Somatic hypermutation  :
Incorrect: Somatic hypermutation involves altering certain nucleotides within the DNA of the B cell receptor variable region. The subsequent replacement of the DNA strand with other nucleotides causes slightly different variable regions, with the goal of developing both higher affinity and diversity of antigen-binding.

questions.text: A study is done on the inflammatory response in the body. The study found that many immune cells and cytokines play a role in coordinating the immune response. One of the primary cells involved was macrophages. Which of the following is true about the roles of macrophages and the cytokines it produces?

choices.text: Macrophages secrete interleukin-8, which mediates fever
Macrophages secrete Interleukin-2 (IL-2) which stimulates other immune cells.
Macrophages secrete Interleukin-4 (IL-4) which mediates the differentiation of T-helper cells into Th2 cells.
Macrophages secrete IL-12 which activates natural killer cells and induce T-helper cells differentiation into Th2 cells.
Macrophages secrete IL-12 which activates natural killer cells and induce T-helper cells differentiation into Th1 cells.

questions.solution:
Macrophages are phagocytes that are part of innate immunity. They are one of the most important cells involved in inflammation. These cells are normally inactive, but once activated by various immune signals, they not only perform their functions of phagocytosis but also release many cytokines that modulate the immune response. The most notable cytokines produced by macrophages are Interleukin-1 (IL-1), interleukin-6 (IL-6), interleukin-12 (IL-12), and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-a). These cytokines help in the defense against bacterial and viral infections, as well as in destroying tumor cells.  

  • IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-a are major proinflammatory cytokines. They target various immune cells but also act on the liver to produce acute phase reactants and on the brain to induce fever. Although their effects are important to the function of the immune system, these cytokines are also implicated in certain diseases, like the excessive secretion of IL-1 and TNF, leading to septic shock and multiorgan failure due to excessive generalized inflammation.  
  • TNF is one of the most potent cytokines.  As discussed earlier, it induces fever and increased acute phase reactants production and is also involved in the pathogenesis of sepsis. TNF also suppresses the appetite and is responsible for cachexia in cancer patients. Additionally, TNF causes vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, which allows immune cells to reach the inflammatory site.   

  • IL-1 (especially IL-1B) is mainly produced by macrophages but also by lymphocytes, natural killer cells, and fibroblasts. IL-1 actions include inducing fever, increased acute phase reactants production, and increased expression of adhesion molecules on the leukocytes and endothelial cells, thereby facilitating the leukocytes to reach the inflammatory site and increasing the production of other proinflammatory cytokines.   

  • IL-6 is mainly involved in stimulating fever and increasing the production of acute-phase reactants.   

  • IL-8 is a major chemoattractant for neutrophils to the site of inflammation  

  • IL-12 is mainly produced by macrophages and plays a crucial role in the defense against infections and cancers. It induces the differentiation of T-cells into Th1 cells, which then secretes cytokines (e.g. IFN-Y) that drive the immune system. IL-12 also activates natural killer cells and thereby activates cell-mediated immunity.   

Option Analysis

❌ Macrophages secrete interleukin-8, which mediates fever  :
Incorrect: Macrophages secrete IL-1, IL-6, and TNF, all of which mediate fever. It also secretes IL-8, a chemoattractant for neutrophils but not involved in inducing fever.  
❌ Macrophages secrete Interleukin-2 (IL-2) which stimulates other immune cells.  :
Incorrect: IL-2 is produced by T-cells, not macrophages.  
❌ Macrophages secrete Interleukin-4 (IL-4) which mediates the differentiation of T-helper cells into Th2 cells.   :
Incorrect: IL-4 is produced by Th2 cells, not by macrophages  
❌ Macrophages secrete IL-12 which activates natural killer cells and induce T-helper cells differentiation into Th2 cells.  :
Incorrect: IL-12 is secreted by macrophages, which activates natural killer cells. However, it induces the differentiation of T helper cells into Th1 cells, not Th2 cells.  
✅ Macrophages secrete IL-12 which activates natural killer cells and induce T-helper cells differentiation into Th1 cells.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A researcher is studying cells produced by hematopoietic stem cells. One of the cells that is being studied is a lymphocyte that has CD3 and CD8 receptors on its surface. This type of cell originates from the bone marrow. Which of the following is the location where this cell differentiates to become a mature lymphocyte?
questions.solution:
The cell described in the question is a cytotoxic T lymphocyte. Lymphocytes are the main drivers of the adaptive immune response, and there are two types of lymphocytes, B lymphocytes (B cells) and T lymphocytes (T cells). Both lymphocytes originate from the hematopoietic stem cells in the bone marrow; however, they differentiate into mature forms in different organs.  

B cells become immature B cells from the common lymphoid progenitor cells (B cell precursors) and then mature into plasma cells in the lymph nodes and the spleen.   

On the other hand, T cell precursors in the bone marrow leave for the thymus, where they become mature T lymphocytes.  


Option Analysis

✅ Thymus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lymph nodes  :
Incorrect: B-cells mature into plasma cells in the lymph nodes and the spleen, and T cells mature in the thymus.  
❌ Spleen:
Incorrect: B-cells mature into plasma cells in the lymph nodes and the spleen, whereas T cells mature in the thymus.  
❌ Bone marrow  :
Incorrect: T cell precursors are produced in the bone marrow from hematopoietic stem cells, which then leave the bone marrow to the thymus to mature into a T lymphocyte.  
❌ Bloodstream:
Incorrect: T cells mature in the thymus, not the bloodstream.

questions.text: A 4-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatrician by his mother for follow-up. The mother asks the pediatrician about the vaccines that her child must receive. He was diagnosed with severe-combined immunodeficiency (SCID) at two months. Which of the following vaccines are contraindicated in this child?
questions.solution:
Live attenuated vaccines are a form of active immunization. Live attenuated vaccines are one type of whole-cell vaccine in which the recipient is injected with a live form of a pathogen. In live-attenuated vaccines, the pathogen is weakened but not killed; therefore, it is less pathogenic but can replicate inside the host’s body. The replicating pathogen then activates the adaptive immune system that involves both the humoral and the cellular immune systems, resulting in a strong immune response nearly as strong as a typical infection.  This is the primary advantage of live-attenuated vaccines because the immunity produced by such vaccines is the strongest and longest-lasting of all types of vaccination and can last up to several decades after a single immunization.  

However, live-attenuated vaccines have some side effects. Because the living form of the pathogen is injected, it can, in some cases, cause disease, especially in patients with low immunity (e.g., patients with AIDS and patients with severe combined immunodeficiency). Therefore, live-attenuated vaccines are contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.   

Examples of live-attenuated vaccines include the Mumps-Measles-Rubella vaccine, rotavirus vaccine, intranasal influenza vaccine, chickenpox, smallpox vaccine, and yellow fever vaccine.   

Option Analysis

✅ Rotavirus vaccine  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hepatitis B vaccine  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B is a subunit vaccine that can be administered to patients with immunodeficiencies.  
❌ Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine  :
Incorrect: DTaP is not contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies because it is not a live-attenuated vaccine.  
❌ Streptococcus pneumoniae vaccine  :
Incorrect: The Streptococcus pneumoniae vaccine is a subunit vaccine that is not contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.  
❌ Intramuscular influenza vaccine  :
Incorrect: Intramuscular influenza is a killed vaccine that can be safely given to patients with immunodeficiencies.

questions.text: A study is done to determine the different cells in the blood and their function. A peripheral blood smear was taken and examined, and the image is shown below. The cell identified by the arrow does which of the following functions?

choices.text: Promote class switching for antibodies produced by B-cells

questions.solution:
Eosinophils are leukocytes that are part of the innate immune system. They are granulocytes that contain many granules in their cytoplasm. These granules can help differentiate eosinophils because they stain pink with eosin stain. Eosinophils are larger than neutrophils, and they are characterized by their bilobed nucleus.   

Eosinophils have many functions in the immune system. They are phagocytes like neutrophils. These cells have specific functions in defending against helminthic infections due to their ability to recognize and phagocyte these infections. Additionally, they have the ability to phagocyte immune complexes which help clear them from the tissues. Finally, eosinophils are involved in allergic reactions, where they degranulate and release histamine and many proinflammatory cytokines when an allergen enters the body.


Option Analysis

✅ Defend against helminthic infections  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Defend against viral infections  :
Incorrect: Eosinophils are not involved in the defense against viral infections.  
❌ Promote class switching for antibodies produced by B-cells  :
Incorrect: T-helper lymphocytes are responsible for inducing class switching in the antibodies produced by B-cells. This is not a function of eosinophils.  
❌ Kill neoplastic cells   :
Incorrect: Eosinophils are not involved in detecting and killing neoplastic cells.
❌ Produce antibodies  :
Incorrect: Eosinophils do not produce antibodies.

questions.text: A study is organized on the structure of antibodies to determine the role of the different parts in it. An illustration of the structure of an antibody is shown below. Which of the following is true regarding the region marked with the letter A?

choices.text: It determines the isotype of the antibody.
It is made of both heavy chains and light chains.
It is made of light chains only.
It determines the idiotype of the antibody.
It is the antigen binding site of the antibody.

questions.solution:
Antibodies are a crucial component of the adaptive immune system that is produced and secreted by B-cells. There are 5 different isotypes of antibodies which are IgM, IgD, IgG, IgA, and IgE. Each antibody is specific for only one antigen.  

The structure of the antibody is made up of both heavy and light chains and is divided into 2 fragments: the fragment antigen binding (Fab region) and the constant fragment (Fc region).  

The Fab region is the area for antigen binding and is made of both heavy and light chains. It determines the idiotype of the antibody, where it is unique for only one antigen.  

The Fc region determines the isotype of the antibody and is made up only of heavy chains.  

Antibodies can be found attached to B-cells and also secreted in the blood. The two types of antibodies that are found on naïve B cells are IgM and IgD.  

Option Analysis

✅ It determines the isotype of the antibody.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is made of both heavy chains and light chains.  :
Incorrect: The constant (Fc) region in the antibody (marked with the letter A) is only made of heavy chains.
❌ It is made of light chains only.  :
Incorrect: The constant (Fc) region in the antibody (marked with the letter A) is only made of heavy chains.  
❌ It determines the idiotype of the antibody.  :
Incorrect: The constant (Fc) region of the antibody determines the isotope of the antibody, while the fragment antigen binding region (Fab region) determines the idiotype of the antibody (marked with the letter B).  
❌ It is the antigen binding site of the antibody.  :
Incorrect: The fragment antigen binding region (Fab region) is the site for antigen binding (marked with the letter B).

questions.text: A patient’s immune system is exposed to a virus and subsequently forms memory B- and T cells to its antigens. One year later, the patient’s immune system is exposed to this virus again. Which of the following is true regarding the patient’s secondary immune response?

choices.text: Only B cells that do not undergo class switching can become memory B cells
The secondary immune response requires a higher pathogen burden
Memory T cells with lower levels of IL-7 receptors will live much longer
Follicular helper T cells respond to carbohydrate and lipid antigens
IgG antibodies can bind to receptors on B cells, preventing formation of IgM plasma cells

questions.solution:
A primary immune response occurs the first time the body encounters novel antigens. Naïve B- and T cells require a high level of pathogen burden so that there is plenty of antigen available for them to bind and undergo subsequent maturation. Since this antigen is new, the primary immune response can take days to weeks to occur. Some of these activated B- and T cells go on to become memory cells, which are major components of the secondary immune response. The secondary immune response occurs when the previous antigen is encountered again and requires much less pathogen burden, and occurs more quickly since there are already memory B- and T cells that “remember” the antigen.  

Memory B cells are formed after a B cell binds to a follicular dendritic cell, and then presents a peptide antigen to a follicular helper T cell. This process causes the B cell to class switch to either an IgA, IgE or IgG plasma cell. IgG antibodies have a much higher affinity than IgM antibodies. In addition, IgG antibodies can bind to the Fc gamma receptor II on newly-formed B cells, preventing them from becoming IgM-secreting plasma cells. This helps keep up a large pool of high-affinity IgG plasma cells.  

Memory T cells can either be effector memory cells or central memory cells. Effector memory cells move throughout the body looking for the antigen they “remember.” These effector cells can function as CD4+ helper T cells or CD8+ cytotoxic T cells. Effector memory T cells express lower levels of IL-7 receptors after they engage in an immune response, so they die shortly after the response. Central memory T cells stay in lymphoid tissues and maintain a high level of IL-7 receptors. Due to this, they can live up to 25 years. When they encounter an antigen, they “remember,” they will proliferate and create new T cells which can then respond to the antigen.  

Option Analysis

❌ Only B cells that do not undergo class switching can become memory B cells  :
Incorrect: Only B cells that undergo class switching (with the help of follicular dendritic cells and T cells) can become memory B cells. Class switching involves changing from an IgD- and IgM-predominant B cell to either an IgA, IgE or IgG B cell.  
❌ The secondary immune response requires a higher pathogen burden  :
Incorrect: The secondary immune response requires a much lower pathogen burden than the primary immune response since a person has already formed memory B- and T cells to that pathogen and its antigens.  
❌ Memory T cells with lower levels of IL-7 receptors will live much longer  :
Incorrect: Memory T cells that express large amounts of IL-7 receptors (e.g. central memory T cells) live much longer than those which express small amounts of IL-7 receptors (e.g. effector memory T cells).
❌ Follicular helper T cells respond to carbohydrate and lipid antigens  :
Incorrect: Follicular helper T cells only respond to peptide antigens. Thus, memory B cells can only respond to peptide antigens, since they first must undergo class switching by presenting peptide antigens to follicular helper T cells.  
✅ IgG antibodies can bind to receptors on B cells, preventing formation of IgM plasma cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text: A 24-year-old man comes to the physician because of an itchy rash on his right arm. The rash began one day ago as small papules and progressed into blisters with oozing. He was weeding plants in a public yard a few days ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's arm is shown. There is no lymphadenopathy. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this disease?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an itchy, red, vesicular rash characteristic of contact dermatitis secondary to possible poison ivy exposure and a type IV (delayed-type) hypersensitivity reaction.   

Type IV hypersensitivity reaction involves damage to surrounding tissue via CD8+ T cells (also known as killer T cells or cytotoxic T cells) and CD4+ T cells, also known as helper T cells. The former targets antigens as presented on MHC class I molecules via their T-cell receptors (TCR). This results in the release of perforin and granzymes, inducing lysis of the presenting cell.  

CD4+ T cells, on the other hand, become activated when the antigen is presented to them on MHC class II molecules via an antigen-presenting cell or APC (e.g. Langerhans cells). The CD4+ T cells bind to these molecules via TCR and a CD4 co-receptor. In addition, the CD4+ T cell also expresses a surface CD28 protein which binds to the B7 protein on the surface of the APC. Ultimately, this series of interactions results in the release of interleukin 12 from the APC,  inducing differentiation of CD4+ naive T cells into type 1 helper T (TH1) cells. These cells release interleukin-2 (IL-2), which helps TH1 cells and other T cells proliferate, and interferon-gamma activates phagocytes to create more TH1 cells. Activated macrophages release proinflammatory cytokines, including tumor necrosis factor, interleukin-1, and interleukin-6, enhancing endothelial barrier permeability. These mediators allow more immune cells to enter the area of inflammation, leading to local swelling or edema, redness, and warmth and inducing systemic symptoms like fever.  

Option Analysis

❌ Complement-dependent reaction  :
Incorrect: With a complement-dependent reaction, antibody bound to antigen fixes to complement and induces direct cell lysis through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Complement-dependent reactions include Goodpasture syndrome, rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection.  
❌ Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity  :
Incorrect: With antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction), cell types that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate removal of an antigen. Examples include transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.  
❌ Immune complex-mediated complement activation  :
Incorrect: Immune complex-mediated complement activation defines the mechanism of a type III hypersensitivity reaction, characterized by the deposition of IgG-antigen complexes in various tissues. Examples include polyarteritis nodosa, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, and lupus nephritis. This patient presents with anaphylaxis, which is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.  
✅ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ IgE-mediated mast cell activation  :
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE and mast cells and are associated with hives, bronchospasm, and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A study was done on the complement system to determine their functions in the immune response. It was found that one of the complement proteins covers the surface of bacteria and aids in phagocytosis. Which of the following is the most likely complement protein that does this function?
questions.solution:
The complement system is made of proteins that once activated, play an important role in the fight against pathogens.  

The main function of the complement occurs when C5b becomes activated, which then joins the complex from C6 to C9 and forms the membrane attack complex (MAC) which forms pores in the membranes of bacteria (specifically Gram-negative bacteria) and leads to cell lysis. The MAC is especially important in defending against Neisseria infections, and people with deficiencies in these complement proteins can develop recurrent and life-threatening infections with Neisseria species (e.g., meningococcal pneumonia).  

However, the MAC is not the only way the complement system helps in the immune response. Certain fragments of activated complement proteins also have unique functions in the immune response.  First of all, C3b also functions as an opsonin by covering the bacteria and tagging them for phagocytes. This makes the process of phagocytosis more efficient.  

Additionally, C3a and C5a act as chemotactic factors, where they help direct the neutrophils and other immune cells (e.g., macrophages, and eosinophils) to the site of inflammation. Additionally, these 2 complement proteins act as anaphylatoxins, meaning that they help in the degranulation of basophils and mast cells and the release of histamine.  

Finally, C1, C2, C3, and C4 help in clearing immune complexes. This prevents excessive inflammation and tissue damage. Patients with deficiencies of these factors may develop lupus-like syndrome due to the inability to clear immune complexes, which they deposit in various organs.  

Option Analysis

✅ C3b:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ C3a:
Incorrect: C3a functions in anaphylaxis and chemotaxis. However, it does not have opsonin ability.  
❌ C5a:
Incorrect: C5a has similar functions to C3a with anaphylaxis and chemotaxis. However, it does not have opsonin ability.  
❌ C9:
Incorrect: C9 is part of the membrane attack complex. However, it is not an opsonin.  
❌ C4b:
Incorrect: C4b joins C2b to form the C4b2b complex (C3 convertase) which converts C3 to C3a and C3b. It does not act as an opsonin.

questions.text: Two sets of preventive treatments are discussed in evaluating the management of tetanus. One approach is to give patients anti-tetanus immunoglobulins, and the other is to provide a tetanus toxoid vaccine. Which of the following is true regarding the two preventive approaches?

choices.text: The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin results in a longer-lasting immune response than the tetanus toxoid vaccine.
Both the anti-tetanus immunoglobulin and the tetanus toxoid vaccine activate the humoral and cellular response in the host body.
Anti-tetanus immunoglobulin activates the humoral immune response in the host, while the tetanus toxoid vaccine activates the humoral and cellular immunity.
The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin and the tetanus toxoid vaccine result in the formation of memory cells.
The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin results in a faster immune response than the tetanus toxoid vaccine.

questions.solution:
Two forms of immunization are currently used to prevent and treat infectious diseases: passive and active.  

Passive immunization refers to the transfer of preformed antibodies from an immunized individual to a non-immunized individual. This can occur naturally, like the transfer of IgG antibodies from the mother to the child through the placenta and the transfer of IgA antibodies through breast milk. Alternatively, it can be done artificially by taking antibodies from an immunized individual and transferring them to another individual who is not immunized.  

In passive immunization, the preformed antibodies transferred are functional as soon as they reach the host’s body and therefore serve a faster immune response than active vaccination forms.  

Passive immunization does not activate the host immune system; therefore, this immunity is short and lasts only until the antibodies transferred disappear. Also, no memory cells develop because the host's adaptive immunity is not activated.  

On the other hand, active immunity develops after exposure to an infectious agent, either naturally through infection or by vaccination. This form of immunity causes the activation of the host's adaptive immune system, resulting in the formation of immune B- and T-cells capable of defending against the infectious agent. Additionally, memory cells develop active immunity and hence can mount a fast immune response if the infectious agent is exposed to it again.  

Option Analysis

❌ The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin results in a longer-lasting immune response than the tetanus toxoid vaccine.:
Incorrect: Passive immunization (anti-tetanus immunoglobulins) results in a shorter immune response than active immunization (tetanus toxoid vaccine).
❌ Both the anti-tetanus immunoglobulin and the tetanus toxoid vaccine activate the humoral and cellular response in the host body.  :
Incorrect: An anti-tetanus immunoglobulin is a form of passive immunization which does not activate the host adaptive immune system.  
❌ Anti-tetanus immunoglobulin activates the humoral immune response in the host, while the tetanus toxoid vaccine activates the humoral and cellular immunity.  :
Incorrect: An anti-tetanus immunoglobulin is a form of passive immunization which does not activate the host adaptive immune system.  
❌ The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin and the tetanus toxoid vaccine result in the formation of memory cells.:
Incorrect: Because the anti-tetanus immunoglobulin is a passive immunity, it does not result in the formation of memory cells.  
✅ The anti-tetanus immunoglobulin results in a faster immune response than the tetanus toxoid vaccine.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A peripheral smear is taken from a patient and is examined under the microscope. One type of cell was identified and is shown in the picture below (marked with a black arrow). Which of the following is true about this cell?

choices.text: It is part of the adaptive immune response.
It helps in killing cancerous cells.
It presents foreign antigens to lymphocytes.

questions.solution:
Neutrophils are polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) with a multilobed nucleus (2-5 lobes). They are the most abundant granulocytes in the blood and they contain many granules (azurophilic and specific granules).  

Neutrophils are the main cells responsible for acute inflammation. They help defend against bacterial infections by phagocytosis. Once the bacteria is phagocytosed, it is destroyed via lysosomes or by oxidative bursts.  

Option Analysis

❌ It is part of the adaptive immune response.  :
Incorrect: Neutrophils are part of the innate immune system, not the adaptive immune system.  
❌ It helps in killing cancerous cells.  :
Incorrect: Neutrophils do not kill cancerous cells. Natural killer cells and T-cells are responsible for fighting against cancerous cells.  
❌ It defends against helminthic infections.  :
Incorrect: Eosinophils, not neutrophils, defend against helminthic infections.  
❌ It presents foreign antigens to lymphocytes.  :
Incorrect: Neutrophils are not antigen presenting cells. They are incapable of presenting antigens to lymphocytes.  
✅ It defends against bacterial infections.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A group of immunologists are evaluating the human body’s defense mechanisms against pathogens. In their studies, they focused on the differences between the adaptive immune system and the innate immune system. Which of the following statements is true regarding these immune systems?

choices.text: The complement system is part of the innate immune system
The adaptive immune system cells have receptors that recognize surface structures shared between different pathogens but not found on the surface of their own body cells
All the cells of the lymphoid lineage are part of the adaptive immune system
The innate immune system is able to mount a stronger immune response when encountering a pathogen for the second time.
Secreted proteins are only seen in the innate immune system

questions.solution:
The immune system helps defend the body against infections and foreign molecules. It is made up of 2 parts: the innate and the adaptive immune responses.   

The innate immune system is the first-line defense against pathogens invading the body. The innate immune system is made of immune cells, which are macrophages, neutrophils, dendritic cells, and natural killer cells. In addition, it also includes other non-immune parts like the physical barrier of the skin and the secretions and enzymes in the body (e.g. gastric acid). The innate immune system is non-specific, which means that it responds in the same way to different pathogens. One of the features of this system is that it is fast and the immune cells can destroy the foreign body or pathogen within hours of entering the body. However, one of the drawbacks of the innate immune system is the lack of memory, and therefore will not be able to recognize an antigen or a foreign body if encountered again and will respond exactly the same as the first encounter of such antigen.  

Innate immunity against pathogens relies on the pattern recognition receptors (PRR) which recognizes and detects a wide range of pathogens that share common structures called pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs).
