Once they recognize PAMPs, the innate immune cells are able to destroy the pathogens immediately. Examples of PAMPs include lipopolysaccharide (LPS) on the surface of gram-negative bacteria as well as flagellin on the surface of bacteria. These PAMPs are found on the cell surface of the pathogen and therefore surface PRR will be able to recognize them. Additionally, intracellular PRR are able to recognize intracellular PAMPs like viral DNA or RNA.  

On the other hand, the adaptive immune response is made of lymphocytes and antibodies. It is specific against every single pathogen and this leads to a slower reaction than that of innate immunity. However, adaptive immune cells (lymphocytes) are able to form memory cells, and once a pathogen is encountered again, a much stronger and faster response occurs. The adaptive immune cells are capable of secreting immunoglobulins (i.e. antibodies) and cytokines that help modulate the immune response.  

Option Analysis

✅ The complement system is part of the innate immune system  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The adaptive immune system cells have receptors that recognize surface structures shared between different pathogens but not found on the surface of their own body cells  :
Incorrect: Unlike the innate immune system, the adaptive immune system is specific and recognizes each different pathogen by its specific antigens.  
❌ All the cells of the lymphoid lineage are part of the adaptive immune system  :
Incorrect: Natural killer cells originate from the lymphoid lineage, but they are part of the innate immune system.  
❌ The innate immune system is able to mount a stronger immune response when encountering a pathogen for the second time.  :
Incorrect: Unlike the adaptive immune system, the innate immune system does not have memory cells. Therefore, when encountering a pathogen for the second time, the innate immune system will respond the same way it responds to the first encounter.  
❌ Secreted proteins are only seen in the innate immune system  :
Incorrect: Both systems secrete proteins that help in mounting the immune response.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for a 6-hour history of fever, itchy rash, and generalized body aches. Ten days ago, he received a snake bite treatment in the emergency department. Physical examination is significant for fever, an urticarial rash, myalgia, and polyarthritis. Urine dipsticks show 2+ protein. Serum complement levels are reduced. Which is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has serum sickness after receiving anti-snake venom. This condition is a type III hypersensitivity reaction.   

Serum sickness refers to a systemic inflammatory response to the presence of immune complexes. It typically occurs when a patient receives foreign serum and elicits an antibody response against the foreign antigens in the serum. A classic example includes snakebites treated with antivenom serum. In response to this initial episode, the body generates antibodies against the anti-venom antibodies. So if the patient is bitten by a snake again with subsequent administration of serum, antibodies from the initial exposure bind and form immune complexes with the anti-venom antibodies. These immune complexes can deposit and cause vasculitis as well as tissue necrosis.  

Typical serum sickness results in fever, urticaria, arthralgia, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and eosinophilia a few days to two weeks following injection of the foreign serum or drug. Symptoms improve as the immune system removes the antigen and subsides completely when the antigen is eliminated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Arthus reaction  :
Incorrect: Arthus reaction refers to localized inflammation, in contrast to systemic inflammation. Intradermal injection of antigen into a pre-sensitized (has circulating IgG) individual leads to the immune complex formation in the skin (e.g., enhanced local reaction to a booster vaccination).  
✅ Serum sickness  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ IgE-mediated mast cell activation  :
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE and mast cells and can be associated with hives, bronchospasm, and anaphylaxis. It occurs within minutes following the exposure to antigen.  
❌ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells  :
Incorrect: T cell-mediated destruction of antigen-tagged cells is characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity reactions, such as allergic contact dermatitis and exanthematous drug reactions.  
❌ Type II hypersensitivity reaction  :
Incorrect: Type II hypersensitivity reactions occur when antibodies bind to cell-surface antigens resulting in cellular destruction, inflammation, and dysfunction. Serum sickness is a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A study was coordinated to determine the steps in the activation of the complement pathway. In one part of the study, bacteria was added to a sample of blood. It was noted that mannose on the surface of the bacteria led to the activation of a certain protein in the blood involved in the complement system. This activated protein does which of the following steps next?

choices.text: Cleavage of C2 and C4 to form C3 convertase
Cleavage of C3 to form C3a and C3b
Cleavage of C5 to C5a and C5b
Binds to factor B on the surface of the bacteria

questions.solution:
The complement system is made of proteins (complement proteins) that are synthesized in the liver and functions in helping the innate immune system and aids in inflammation.

The complement system is activated via one of three pathways:  

  • The classical pathway  
  • The alternative pathway  
  • The lectin-binding pathway  

The classical pathway starts with C1. C1 has 3 components: C1q, C1r, and C1s. C1q has no enzymatic activity but has a site that binds the Fc portion of the antibody when it is bound to an antigen. On the other hand, C1r and C1s both have serine protease activity but are inactive in normal states. The classical pathway starts when C1q binds to the Fc portion of an antibody bound to an antigen causing conformational changes in the structure of C1, exposing the C1s and C1r, where they can now function. Next, the activated C1 cleaves C2 into C2a and C2b; and C4 into C4a and C4b. C2b and C4b join together and bind to the surface of the pathogen, forming a complex called C4bC2b, or C3 convertase. C3 convertase then cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b where C3b functions as an opsonin. However, a small amount of C3b formed join the C4bC2b on the surface of the antigen forming a new complex called C4bC2bC3b, which is also known C5 convertase, which then cleaves C5 into C5a and C5b. Finally, C5b activates C6 to C9 and this complex (C5b, C6, C7, C8, C9) forms what is known as the membrane attack complex and causes lysis of the cell membrane of the pathogen.  

The lectin-binding pathway starts with a protein called mannose-binding lectin protein, which binds mannose on the surface of microbes (e.g. bacteria) and gets activated. Once activated, mannose-binding lectin protein functions like the activated C1 by cleaving C4 and C2 forming C4b2b complexes (C3 convertase). The rest of the pathway is similar to the classical pathway.  

Finally, there is the alternative pathway. Normally, there is a small amount of C3 that gets cleaved spontaneously into C3a and C3b without the need for C3 convertase. In case a pathogen was present, this C3b binds to the surface of the pathogen. Once it does, a protein called factor B joins C3b on the surface of the pathogen and gets cleaved (by a factor called factor D) into 2 subunits Aa and Bb. Bb remains attached to C3b and together they function as C3 convertase, thus amplifying the cleavage of C3 into C3a and C3b.  

Option Analysis

✅ Cleavage of C2 and C4 to form C3 convertase  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Cleavage of C3 to form C3a and C3b  :
Incorrect: Mannose-binding lectin protein, activated by binding mannose, functions like activated C1 and cleaves C2 and C4. This leads to the formation of the C4b2b complex (C3 convertase) which then cleaves C3 to C3a and C3b. However, mannose-binding lectin does not directly cleave C3.
❌ Binds and activates C1  :
Incorrect: Mannose-binding lectin protein, once activated, acts similarly to C1 and cleaves C2 and C4. However, it does not activate C1.  
❌ Cleavage of C5 to C5a and C5b  :
Incorrect: Mannose-binding lectin does not directly convert C5 to C5a and C5b.  
❌ Binds to factor B on the surface of the bacteria  :
Incorrect: In the alternative pathway, C3b, which forms spontaneously is joined with factor B on the surface of the bacteria, where factor B is then converted to Bb and functions (with C3b) as C3 convertase. However, the mannose-binding lectin pathway does not interact with factor B to activate the complement system.

questions.text: Research is done on the different types of antibodies in the body. The five different types of antibodies (IgA, IgM, IgG,IgE, and IgE) are evaluated. Which of the following is true regarding these antibodies?

choices.text: IgG antibodies are the only antibodies that can cross the placenta.
The most abundant antibody in the serum is IgM antibodies
IgE antibodies are secreted in breast milk
IgG and IgA antibodies can fixate and activate the complement system.
IgD antibodies are the most produced antibodies overall

questions.solution:
Antibodies are produced by B-cells and are part of the adaptive immune response. There are five different types of antibodies produced by B cells which are IgM, IgD, IgG, IgE, and IgA antibodies. The features of each antibody are discussed below.  

IgM antibodies  
IgM antibodies can be found on the surface of B cells as monomers or secreted as pentamers. These antibodies are the first antibodies produced by B cells in the primary (immediate) immune response, and they do not require T cell activation or class switching to be produced. IgM antibodies are able to fixate the complement system, and can also act as opsonins against bacterial pathogens.  


IgD antibodies  
IgD antibodies can also be found on the plasma membrane of B cells and can be secreted. It is not completely understood the function of these antibodies, but are believed to help mature B cells exit the bone marrow.  


IgG antibodies  
IgG antibodies are the most abundant type of antibodies in the plasma. They are secreted in the secondary immune response to an antigen. These antibodies can fixate the complement system, act as opsonins, and help neutralize bacterial toxins and viruses. Also, IgG antibodies are the only type of antibodies that can cross the placenta.  


IgE antibodies  
IgE antibodies are involved in allergic responses, and also in defense against parasitic infections. It has receptors on mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils.  


IgA antibodies  
IgA antibodies are the most produced isotype overall; however, it has a lower plasma concentration. These antibodies prevent pathogens from attaching to the mucosal surfaces and thus causing infections. It is the main antibody found in mucosal sites. IgA antibodies are produced by Peyer’s patches where they leave the mucosal surface by transcytosis, and also secreted in saliva, tears, semen, and breast milk.  


Option Analysis

✅ IgG antibodies are the only antibodies that can cross the placenta.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ The most abundant antibody in the serum is IgM antibodies  :
Incorrect: IgG antibodies are the most abundant antibodies in the serum.  
❌ IgE antibodies are secreted in breast milk  :
Incorrect:  IgE antibodies are not secreted in breast milk. IgA antibodies are secreted in breast milk.  
❌ IgG and IgA antibodies can fixate and activate the complement system.  :
Incorrect: IgG and IgM antibodies are able to fixate and activate the complement system, while IgA antibodies do not activate the complement system.  
❌ IgD antibodies are the most produced antibodies overall  :
Incorrect: IgA antibodies are the most produced antibodies overall but have lower serum concentrations. IgG antibodies are the most abundant isotype in the serum.

questions.text: A researcher evaluates the mechanism of action of a particular vaccine that induces the immune system to produce antibodies against a toxin produced by a bacteria. Still, it does not cause the formation of antibodies against the bacteria itself. Which vaccines work in this mechanism?
questions.solution:
The vaccine in the study is describing a toxoid vaccine. Toxoid vaccines are types of vaccines in which a toxin produced by bacteria is denatured, but the antigens on the toxin are maintained. This will result in antibodies against the toxins that will protect against the toxin in the future. The two vaccines that are used are tetanus and diphtheria vaccines.  

Toxoid vaccines are safe and provide immunity against the toxin. However, the levels of antitoxins may decrease with time, so patients may require booster doses in the future.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diphtheria vaccine  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hepatitis B vaccine  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B vaccine is a subunit vaccine, not a toxoid vaccine  
❌ Rotavirus vaccine  :
Incorrect: Rotavirus vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine, not a toxoid vaccine.  
❌ Intramuscular influenza vaccine  :
Incorrect: Intramuscular influenza vaccine is a killed vaccine, not a toxoid vaccine  
❌ Hepatitis A vaccine  :
Incorrect: Hepatitis A vaccine is a killed vaccine, not a toxoid vaccine.

questions.text: During an evaluation of the inflammatory response against certain bacterial pathogens, an interaction between lymphocytes and macrophages was observed to mediate an immune response. In this interaction, macrophages are exposed to the pathogen and then secreted interleukin-12, which activates a specific lymphocyte to secrete interferon-gamma. Which of the following is the correct match of the source and function of interferon-gamma?

choices.text: Source  Function   Th1 cells   Stimulates the differentiation of Th2 cells

questions.solution:
Cytokines play an important role in the immune response by acting on specific receptors. Hundreds of cytokines are produced by immune cells (e.g., macrophages, lymphocytes) and non-immune cells.  

Some cytokines are produced by T-cells, especially CD4+ cells, which can help the immune system. Interleukin-2 (IL-2) is one of these cytokines that is produced by CD4+ T-helper cells. IL-2 stimulates the growth of lymphocytes, including helper and cytotoxic lymphocytes, and natural killer cells to help perform an immune response. Interleukin-3 (IL-3) is also produced by helper T-cells and acts on the bone marrow to stimulate the production of more immune cells.  

IL-2 and IL-3 are produced by all helper T cells. However, some cytokines are produced specifically by Th1 cells, while others are produced by Th2 cells only.  

The main cytokine produced by Th1 cells is interferon-gamma (IFN-γ). IFN-γ is released from Th1 cells after they are activated by pathogens or by interleukin-12 (IL-12) released from macrophages. IFN-γ then activates the macrophages to make them more efficient in engulfing and killing the pathogens and, in some cases, activates the macrophages to induce the formation of a granuloma. It also activates natural killer cells to kill virally-infected cells while increasing the expression of MHC. Furthermore, IFN-γ can mediate class switching in B-cells to IgG; finally, it inhibits the differentiation of Th2 cells.  

On the other hand, the cytokines released from Th2 cells are mainly geared towards fighting parasitic infections but are also involved in allergic responses (e.g. asthma). These cytokines are IL-4, IL-5,IL-10, and IL-13.  

  • IL-4: Induces the growth and differentiation of Th2 cells. It also stimulates the class switching in B-cells to IgE and IgG. IL-4 also mediates the degranulation of mast cells.  
  • IL-5: Stimulates the B-cells and causes class switching to IgA. It also stimulates the production and growth of eosinophils.  
  • IL-10: An anti-inflammatory cytokine that attenuates the immune system. It targets macrophages and inhibits IL-12 production and thus inhibits the Th1 development; it also targets Th1 cells and inhibits the production of IL-2 and IFN-γ. It also decreases the expression of antigens on MHC II.  
  • IL-13: Stimulates the growth of B-cells and class switching to IgE. It acts with IL-4 in mediating immune responses against parasitic infections as well as in mediating allergic reactions.    

Option Analysis

✅  Source  Function   Th1 cells   Stimulate natural killer cells :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  Source  Function   Th1 cells   Stimulates the differentiation of Th2 cells:
Incorrect: Interferon-gamma inhibits the differentiation of Th2 cells.   
❌  Source  Function   Th2 cells   Decrease MHC expression :
Incorrect: IL-10 produced by Th2 cells attenuates the immune response and decreases MHC expression. However, IFN-γ increases the expression of MHC and is produced by Th1 cells.   
❌  Source  Function   Th2 cells   Enhance class switching to IgA :
Incorrect: This is the function of IL-5 produced by Th2 cells.
❌  Source  Function   Th1 cells   Activates eosinophils :
Incorrect: IL-5 produced by Th2 cells, not Th1 cells, stimulates the production and growth of eosinophils.

questions.text: A maturing T cell undergoes VDJ rearrangement. A strand of DNA containing a V and D gene is looped on itself, and a piece of DNA between these two genes is cut out. These two pieces of DNA are subsequently reattached. Which of the following enzymes is responsible for adding random nucleotides to promote further diversity at this stage of T cell formation?
questions.solution:
B cells and T cells both undergo V(D)J rearrangement during the cell maturation process to promote diversity among antigen-binding at the variable regions of the B cell and T cell receptors. Within the variable regions of the B cell receptor (BCR) and T cell receptor (TCR), the hypervariable region is created when the two chains of the receptor bind together to form the final antigen-binding site. Within these hypervariable regions, V(D)J rearrangement occurs extensively. This process starts with beta-chains in T cells and heavy chains in B cells, where random V, D, and J regions are combined with random nucleotides between them. These resultant cells with incomplete receptors are then tested with multiple other chains (alpha-chains for T cells and light chains for B cells) to ensure they are functional and not self-reactive. Alpha-chains (T cells) and light chains (B cells) only contain V and J regions, so they undergo a similar process but without any D genes. This eventually leads to a pool of immune cells with one chain containing a wide variety of VDJ combinations, which is paired with a wide variety of other chains containing a wide variety of VJ combinations.  

The actual process of V(D)J rearrangement is accomplished via several important enzymes, including recombination-activating gene 1 (RAG1), RAG2, Artemis, Ku DNA-protein-kinase, terminal deoxynucleotide transferase (TdT), and others. Recombination signal sequences flank the V, D, and J regions, and signal the DNA to be looped around that area. RAG1 and RAG2 bind to this area and cut out the non-coding circular DNA. Artemis and Ku DNA-protein-kinase then begin reattaching and recombining the V, D, and J segments without this non-coding DNA. During recombination, TdT inserts random nucleotides between the V, D, and J genes, creating a unique strand of DNA and thus protein, even if the V, D, and J genes are the exact same.   

Option Analysis

❌ Artemis enzyme  :
Incorrect: This repair protein, along with Ku DNA-protein-kinase, recombines DNA sequences that have been cut by RAG1 and RAG2.  
✅ Terminal deoxynucleotide transferase (TdT)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recombination-activating gene 1 (RAG1)  :
Incorrect: RAG1 and RAG2 cut VDJ genes at the recombination signal sequences, allowing for subsequent reattachment of DNA strands without these signal sequences and wasting a circular piece of non-coding DNA.  
❌ Recombination-activating gene 2 (RAG2)  :
Incorrect: RAG1 and RAG2 cut VDJ genes at the recombination signal sequences, allowing for subsequent reattachment of DNA strands without these signal sequences and wasting a circular piece of non-coding DNA.
❌ Ku DNA-protein-kinase  :
Incorrect: This repair protein, along with Artemis, recombines DNA sequences that have been cut by RAG1 and RAG2.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is diagnosed with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis following a history of skin infection. Which of the following best describes the underlying mechanism of this disease?

choices.text: Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells

questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reactions occur when the normally protective immune system responds abnormally, potentially harming the body. In type III hypersensitivity reactions, IgG binds to the antigen (e.g., the drug molecules in circulation) to form an immune complex (antigen-antibody complex). These complexes are usually removed by cells of the monocyte-macrophage system but, in excess, circulate and deposit in blood vessels, the kidneys, and joints. In autoimmune disorders, “self” antigens often elicit antibodies that bind to organ antigens or deposit in organs and tissues. When deposited, the immune complexes initiate a complement cascade that attracts neutrophils resulting in neutrophil lysis or phagocytosis. Finally, environmental antigens such as fungal spores and certain medications induce immune complex formation.  

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is a well-known immune complex disease that occurs several weeks following a group A β-hemolytic streptococcal infection, particularly of the skin. Lumpy deposits of immunoglobulin and complement components, C3, are observed along the glomerular basement membrane. Complement levels are typically low, suggesting an antigen-antibody reaction with corresponding consumption.  

Additional examples of type III hypersensitivity include rheumatoid arthritis, reactive arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).   

Option Analysis

❌ Complement-dependent reaction  :
Incorrect: With a complement-dependent reaction, antibody bound to antigen fixes to complement and induces direct cell lysis through the production of the membrane attack complex (MAC). Examples include Goodpasture syndrome, rheumatic fever, and hyperacute transplant rejection.  
❌ Antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity  :
Incorrect: With antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity (cellular destruction), cell types that bear receptors for the Fc portion of IgG, such as neutrophils, eosinophils, macrophages, and natural killer (NK) cells, mediate removal of an antigen. Examples include transfusion reactions, erythroblastosis fetalis, and autoimmune hemolytic anemia.  
✅ Immune complex-mediated complement activation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation  
❌ Cytotoxic T-cell destruction of antigen-tagged cells  :
Incorrect: T cell-mediated destruction of antigen-tagged cells is characteristic of type IV hypersensitivity reactions, such as allergic contact dermatitis and exanthematous drug reactions.  
❌ IgE-mediated mast cell activation  :
Incorrect: Type I hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by IgE and mast cells and are associated with hives, bronchospasm, and anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A group of scientists are investigating the role of macrophages in different tissues. They noted that macrophages in different tissues all have the same origins from the bone marrow and monocytes. Which of the following is the correct match of the macrophage and the tissue it resides in?
questions.solution:
Macrophages are one of the most important cells in regulating inflammation and tissue homeostasis. They are produced in the bone marrow as monocytes which are secreted into the blood. Once monocytes leave the blood, they are called macrophages. Macrophages are found in different tissues around the body and there are some resident macrophages in different tissues. These macrophages may have different roles, but they all originate from the bone marrow and the monocytes in the blood. These macrophages have different names according to the tissue they are found in:  

  • Kupffer cells: liver  
  • Osteoclasts: bone  
  • Langerhans cells: skin  
  • Histiocytes: connective tissue  
  • Microglial cells: Central nervous system  

Option Analysis

✅  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Kupffer cells   Liver :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Kupffer cells   Connective tissue :
Incorrect: Histiocytes are macrophages residing in connective tissue, while Kupffer cells are macrophages residing in the liver   
❌  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Monocytes   Peripheral tissues :
Incorrect: Monocytes are only found in the blood, and once they leave tissues they are called macrophages.   
❌  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Langerhans cells   Bone:
Incorrect: Osteoclasts are macrophages residing in the bones, while Langerhans cells are found in the skin.   
❌  Macrophage  Tissue of residence  Langerhans cells   Connective tissue :
Incorrect: Macrophages in connective tissue are called histiocytes, and in the skin are called Langerhans cells.

questions.text: A group of researchers are studying cells involved in both innate and adaptive immune responses. They identify a specific cell of the innate immune system that uses perforin and granzymes to induce apoptosis of virally infected cells and tumor cells. Which of the following cell types is most likely mediating the response described above?
questions.solution:
Natural killer cells (NK) serve as an important component of the innate immune system and cell-mediated immunity. NK cells use both perforin and granzymes to induce apoptosis of virally infected cells and tumor cells. These cells are induced to kill when exposed to a nonspecific activation signal on a target cell. NK cells also kill via antibody-dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity, where CD16 binds the Fc region of bound IgG.  

Similarly, CD8+ T cells directly kill virus-infected and tumor cells via perforin and granzymes. While also being a component of cell-mediated immunity like NK cells,  these cells are part of the adaptive, rather than innate immune response. Cytotoxic T cells require priming and will only engage with specific antigens to kill viruses, intracellular bacteria, and tumor cells. Thus, cytotoxic T cells do this in an antigen-specific manner, looking for their specific antigen expressed on the MHC I molecule of the target cell.  

Option Analysis

✅ Natural killer cells  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ B-cells  :
Incorrect: B-cells are responsible for antibody production. These cells differentiate into plasma cells to secrete specific immunoglobulins.  
❌ CD4+ T cells  :
Incorrect: CD4+ T cells help B cells make antibodies and produce cytokines to recruit phagocytes and activate other leukocytes.  
❌ Hematopoietic stem cells  :
Incorrect: Hematopoietic stem cells are precursor cells and are not involved in cell-mediated cytotoxicity.  
❌ Regulatory T cells  :
Incorrect: Regulatory T cells help maintain specific immune tolerance by suppressing CD4+ and CD8+ T-cell effector functions.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician to take the influenza vaccine. He tells the physician that he read about two types of vaccines available against influenza. The physician agrees with the patient and tells him about the two forms of influenza vaccine: the intranasal and intramuscular forms. The patient was given the intramuscular influenza vaccine. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the intramuscular influenza vaccine?

choices.text: It induces an immune response that is mainly humoral.
It has no differences from the intranasal influenza vaccine.
It is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.
It induces a strong humoral and cellular immune response.

questions.solution:
Inactivated vaccines are whole-cell vaccines where the pathogen is killed or inactivated using heat or chemicals (e.g. formalin) and then injected into the body. The inactivation does not alter the antigen structure; therefore, once injected, the vaccine will stimulate the adaptive immune system to produce an immune response. This vaccine is safe and has fewer side effects than live attenuated vaccines. Additionally, it can be given to pregnant women and patients with immunodeficiencies.  

However, inactivated or killed vaccines result in an immune response that is mainly humoral, with little to no involvement of the cellular immune system (i.e. T-cells). This response is weaker than live-attenuated vaccines and lasts for a shorter period. Therefore, booster doses are usually required as the immunity wanes.  

Examples of inactivated or killed vaccines include intramuscular influenza, polio vaccine, rabies vaccine, and hepatitis A vaccine.    

Option Analysis

✅ It induces an immune response that is mainly humoral.  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ It is a live-attenuated vaccine.  :
Incorrect: The intramuscular influenza vaccine is inactivated, while the intranasal influenza vaccine is live attenuated.  
❌ It has no differences from the intranasal influenza vaccine.  :
Incorrect: The intramuscular influenza vaccine is inactivated, while the intranasal influenza vaccine is live attenuated.  
❌ It is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.  :
Incorrect: The intramuscular influenza vaccine is inactivated and not contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies. In contrast, the intranasal influenza vaccine is live-attenuated and is contraindicated in patients with immunodeficiencies.  
❌ It induces a strong humoral and cellular immune response.  :
Incorrect: Intramuscular influenza vaccine is an inactivated vaccine. This type of vaccine mainly induces a humoral immune response with little or no cellular response. On the other hand, live attenuated vaccines cause strong humoral and cellular immune responses.

questions.text: A bacterial antigen is presented to a CD4+ T-cell via the MHC II protein. Which additional signals must be present on the antigen-presenting cell for T-cell activation to occur?
questions.solution:
T-cell activation requires two signals. The first is the interaction between a T-cell receptor (TCR) and a major histocompatibility protein (MHC). The second is the interaction between the ligand B7 and receptor CD28.    

Antigens are presented to T-cells via MHCs found on the surface of antigen-presenting cells. MHC I typically presents endogenous antigens (e.g. viral or tumor proteins), whereas MHC II typically presents exogenous antigens (e.g. bacterial proteins).      

The first signal is transmitted when MHC I binds to the T-cell receptor (TCR) and CD8 co-receptor on CD8+ T-cells or when MHC II binds to the TCR and CD4 co-receptor on CD4+ T-cells. Of note, the antigen presented by the MHC molecule must be of the right size and shape to bind strongly with a TCR and trigger signal transmission. The second signal occurs when CD28 on the T-cell surface binds with B7 (CD80/86) on the antigen-presenting cell.      

In contrast, if a T-cell interacts with an MHC-antigen complex but does not receive the second signal, it will become anergic. This extra layer of security helps maintain self-tolerance when the body’s immune system will not attack antigens expressed by its organs.    

Once a T-cell has received both signals, it will begin synthesizing inflammatory cytokines. In particular, IL-2 is released and binds to T-cell receptors in a process termed autocrine (self) stimulation, leading to T-cell proliferation and differentiation.  


Option Analysis

❌ CD40:
Incorrect: CD40 is a receptor found on B-cells. The binding of CD40L, which is present on T-cells, with CD40 leads to B-cell activation and increased immunoglobulin production. In contrast, CD40 is not required for T-cell activation.  
❌ IL-2:
Incorrect: Interleukin 2 (IL-2) is a cytokine produced primarily by activated CD4+ and CD8+ T-cells. IL-2 plays an important role in promoting T-cells proliferation and differentiation. However, IL-2 is neither necessary for the initial activation of T-cells nor found on antigen-presenting cells.  
✅ B7:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ MHC I:
Incorrect: Major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC I) proteins typically present endogenous antigens to CD8+ T-cells. The complex formed by the antigen and MHC I molecule is one of the signals necessary for CD8+ T-cell activation. In contrast, MHC I is not typically involved in CD4+ T-cell activation.   
❌ Tumor necrosis factor-alpha:
Incorrect: Tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) is a cytokine produced by monocytes during acute inflammation. TNF-α is involved in regulating the immune response, recruiting leukocytes, and helping maintain granulomas. However, TNF-α is not a signal that must be present with the MHC-antigen complex to induce T-cell activation.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man presents to a rural clinic for evaluation of fevers and abdominal pain, which have been ongoing for the past month. Laboratory testing demonstrates an elevated eosinophil count and elevated IgE level. ELISA testing confirms the presence of Toxocara cana antigens. Which of the following is released by the type of T-cell involved in mediating these laboratory changes and helping the body fight this infection?
questions.solution:
Type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells play a major role in fighting parasitic infections. They stimulate mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils and release IL-4, promoting B-cell class switching to IgE.  

The various types of T-cells release different cytokines. A comparison of the cytokines released by each cell type can be found below.



Option Analysis

❌ Interferon-gamma:
Incorrect: Interferon-gamma (IFNγ) stimulates macrophages to kill phagocytosed organisms. It can also activate natural killer cells and cause them to eliminate virally-infected cells. However, IFNγ is not typically produced by type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells, which are the type of T-cells primarily involved in fighting parasitic infections.  
❌ Interleukin 17:
Incorrect: Interleukin 17 (IL-17) is produced by type 17 helper (Th17) T-cells. Th17 cells regulate tissue inflammation, activate neutrophils, and fight extracellular infections. However, IL-17 is not typically released by type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells, which recruit mast cells, basophils, and eosinophils and induce immunoglobulin class switching to IgE. These changes ultimately enable Th2 cells to fight parasitic infections.  
✅ Interleukin 4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Complement 3b  :
Incorrect: Complement 3b (C3b) is part of the innate immune system. It can opsonize invading pathogens and mark them for clearance by the immune system. However, complement proteins are not released by T-cells.  
❌ Interleukin 35:
Incorrect: Interleukin 35 (IL-35) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that plays a role in immune suppression. However, it is not released by type 2 helper (Th2) T-cells, which are the type of T-cells primarily involved in fighting parasitic infections.
